channel.title: Comments on: Arabic in Africa and the Problem of Archival Thinking
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: By: John
item.dc:creator: John
item.description:
"The speech of the Prophet is not followed by other speech / Do not follow the sheikh when he disagrees voluntarily"
This line, and the renewed emphasis on Arabic, sounds very much to me like it is springing from Salafi influences... Would you classify those critical of the old establishment as ideological Salafis, salafis with a lower-case "s" (e.g., like Muhammad 'Abdu), or as perhaps coming out of some other part of the Tradition?

“The speech of the Prophet is not followed by other speech / Do not follow the sheikh when he disagrees voluntarily”

This line, and the renewed emphasis on Arabic, sounds very much to me like it is springing from Salafi influences… Would you classify those critical of the old establishment as ideological Salafis, salafis with a lower-case “s” (e.g., like Muhammad ‘Abdu), or as perhaps coming out of some other part of the Tradition?
